title: Lemniscate Containment in a Disc
description: For monic f ∈ ℂ[x], if E = {z : |f(z)| < 1} is connected, is E in a disc of radius 2? YES (Pommerenke 1959). The center is the root centroid. But the width conjecture is FALSE.

meta.author: Erdős-Herzog-Piranian (1958), Pommerenke (1959)
originalContributions: Lean formalization of sublevel sets of polynomials
Definition of open/closed discs in ℂ
Root centroid definition using Vieta's formulas

overview.historicalContext: Erdős, Herzog, and Piranian (1958) posed this question about lemniscates - the sublevel sets of polynomial magnitude. They conjectured both diameter ≤ 2 and width ≤ 2. Pommerenke (1959) proved the disc containment (answering YES) but showed the width conjecture is FALSE.
overview.problemStatement: Let f ∈ ℂ[x] be a monic polynomial and E = {z : |f(z)| < 1}. If E is connected, is E contained in a disc of radius 2?
overview.proofStrategy: The formalization defines sublevel sets, open/closed discs, and root centroids. Pommerenke's theorem is axiomatized: if E is connected, then E ⊆ D(centroid, 2). The width counterexample is also formalized.
keyInsights: The answer is YES - E is contained in a disc of radius 2
The center of this disc can be the root centroid (z₁+...+zₙ)/n
E is connected ⟺ E contains all zeros of f'
The width conjecture is FALSE: width can exceed √3·2^{1/3} ≈ 2.18
The diameter is at most 2 (sharper than the 4 implied by disc containment)

sections.title: Connectivity Characterization
sections.summary: E is connected ⟺ E contains critical points

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #1046 is SOLVED: YES, if E = {z : |f(z)| < 1} is connected, then E is contained in a disc of radius 2 centered at the root centroid. However, the related width conjecture is FALSE (Pommerenke's counterexample).
conclusion.implications: This result shows the subtle geometry of polynomial sublevel sets. While they fit in a disc of radius 2, they can be elongated (width > 2). The connectivity condition is characterized by critical points.
openQuestions: What is the sharp bound on width for connected sublevel sets?
How does the geometry depend on the degree of f?
